### ‚Äã‚ÄãWhisper Leak: A novel side-channel attack on remote language models


üß† **AI ADVANCEMENT**


The article "Whisper Leak: A Novel Side-Channel Attack on Remote Language Models" introduces a new method of exploiting vulnerabilities in remote language models through side-channel attacks. The research reveals that adversaries can extract sensitive data from these models by analyzing indirect information leaked during the model's processing tasks. This form of attack poses significant threats to data security, especially as language models are increasingly integrated into sensitive applications. The study emphasizes the need for heightened security measures and awareness around data privacy when deploying language models in

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/blog/2025/11/07/whisper-leak-a-novel-side-channel-cyberattack-on-remote-language-models/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_6960)**

### EFF Teams Up With AV Comparatives to Test Android Stalkerware Detection by Major Antivirus Apps


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) collaborated with AV-Comparatives to assess the ability of major antivirus applications to detect Android stalkerware, malicious apps that enable unauthorized monitoring of internet users. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of these antivirus solutions in identifying and mitigating the risks posed by stalkerware, which can compromise user privacy and security. Findings from the evaluation highlighted varying levels of detection success among different antivirus apps, underscoring the need for improved measures in recognizing and countering such threats.

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2025/11/eff-teams-av-comparatives-test-android-stalkerware-detection-major-antivirus-apps?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_7978)**

### CISA orders feds to patch Samsung zero-day used in spyware attacks


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has mandated that federal agencies address a zero-day vulnerability discovered in Samsung devices, which has been exploited in spyware attacks. This directive underscores the urgency of mitigating potential security risks posed by the flaw, as it could be leveraged by malicious actors to infiltrate and compromise sensitive government systems. The order aligns with CISA's ongoing efforts to enhance the cybersecurity resilience of federal networks by ensuring that any vulnerabilities are swiftly identified and patched, thereby protecting critical infrastructure from potential

**[Read the full article ‚Ä∫](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/cisa-orders-feds-to-patch-samsung-zero-day-used-in-spyware-attacks/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=weekly_ai_cybersecurity&utm_content=article_3936)**

### ‚ÄòWhisper Leak‚Äô LLM Side-Channel Attack Infers User Prompt Topics


üìä **TECH INSIGHT**


I apologize, but I'm unable to access the full text of the article from the URL provided. However, based on the title, it seems the article discusses a novel side-channel attack called "Whisper Leak." This attack exploits vulnerabilities in large language models (LLMs) to infer the topics of user prompts. Side-channel attacks generally involve gathering information from indirect sources rather than a direct breach of secure communication. The article likely explores how "Whisper Leak" can potentially undermine user privacy by revealing the subjects
